Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Do expected evolutionary trade-offs in enzyme activities manifest at the level of microbial community function?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Respiration is the process by which chemical energy is released in a series of enzyme-catalyzed steps typically involving the consumption of organic (carbon containing) compounds and oxygen, and the production of carbon dioxide and water. The speed at which respiration occurs, and carbon dioxide is produced, increases as temperatures increase. For this reason there is concern that microorganisms living in soil, where much of the world's carbon is stored, will consume more soil carbon under global warming. If they do, they may release more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, potentially accelerating global warming. There is substantial uncertainty as to whether this positive feedback to warming will happen - in part because living things can produce respiratory enzymes that have different temperature sensitivities. The goal of this project is to test whether soil microbes maintain initial increases in respiration when temperatures rise, or whether over time they decrease respiration in a way that is consistent with production of less temperature-sensitive enzymes. To quantify soil microbes, this 3-year project will use DNA-sequencing and fatty-acid profiling methodologies. To determine respiration rates, carbon dioxide production from soils will be measured using gas-analysis techniques. To generate differences in temperatures to which microbes are exposed, soils will be collected across a gradient from the arctic to the tropics, in winter and in summer, and incubated in the laboratory at different temperatures.

Results of this project will be important because they will help improve predictions of soil microbial responses and feedbacks to future climate changes, facilitating development of management strategies to mitigate impacts of global warming on humans and ecosystems. From the perspective of basic science, it will help scientists determine whether responses inside microbial cells can alter ecosystem processes that influence the climate system. From education and training perspectives, the project solidifies collaborations between three assistant professors in schools within the U.S. The professors will train the next generation of U.S scientists by advising undergraduate students in conducting independent research. Furthermore, doctoral students will be trained through an interdisciplinary workshop integrating microbiology and ecosystem science. As microbes are the engines that drive the biogeochemical processes on which life depends, this integration is important to help guide sustainable management of the planet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth system models – which society relies on for planning environmental-change mitigation and adaptation – are built on the assumption that climate and plants primarily determine carbon storage in terrestrial ecosystems. The largest store of carbon in these ecosystems is in the soil. Disturbances that degrade ecosystems release this carbon into the atmosphere – in forms such as CO2 – contributing to changing climate. Yet, carbon reservoirs in soils influence more than climate: they are intimately tied to soil health, which is essential for biodiversity and sustainable agricultural production. Our research shows that soil microorganisms have effects on the breakdown of soil carbon reservoirs that contrast with what we would expect if this breakdown were controlled only by climate and plant inputs. Specifically, our research reveals two important findings. First, dominant soil microorganisms adapt to changing temperature conditions, meaning that their initial response to warming is not a reliable predictor of their longer-term response. The implications of this finding for the management of soil carbon stocks under changing climate is ambiguous however, because putting this understanding into organic matter models causes soil carbon loss or no change depending on the type of model used. Our results therefore emphasize the need to determine how best to incorporate soil microbial responses to warming into modeling efforts, so that we can make more reliable projections of how soil carbon stocks, and hence soil health and influence on climate, will respond under ongoing climate change. Second, and also important for determining the best way to incorporate microbial responses to temperature into organic matter models, our findings show that the assumptions we make when modeling decomposition are determined to a large extent by the methodological approaches we use to study this process. That is, the expectation that climate is the predominant control on decomposition is based on assessing the average response of decomposition to climate controls. Yet there is a growing appreciation in other areas of ecological science (e.g. species conservation) that controls identified from mean responses can be irrelevant and misleading. Instead, work in those areas show how analyses based on individual-level data (versus averages) can lead to very different projections of phenomena such as species range shifts under changing climate. In line with these other fields of enquiry, our work shows that climate appears to be a weaker control when decomposition data are considered at the individual versus average level. Specifically, our work shows that the conventional assumption that climate is a predominant control on decomposition is not supported when local-scale variation is explicitly evaluated. Soil microorganisms still emerge as the primary agents of decomposition, but local-level controls assume substantial importance when one considers individual-level data. Identifying these local-level controls will provide direction for how local management can be used to counteract the negative effects on decomposition of broader-scale disturbances such as changing climate. Through this research we have been able to put into place an internship program that helps ensure underrepresented groups in higher education matriculate in STEM-disciplines by retaining them in the educational environment in their summer between high school and college.
